title: Las Vegas Sands Stock Is Rising Because It’s Joining the S&P 500
text:
Text size

Las Vegas Sands stock is climbing on Friday, on news that the casino operator will join the S&P 500.

The back story. Luck hasn’t been a lady for Las Vegas Sands stock (ticker: LVS) lately. The shares are up just 7.4% year to date, compared to a nearly 19% gain for the S&P 500 and a 21% climb for the Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLY). Other gaming stocks, including Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts International (MGM), and Melco Resorts & Entertainment (MLCO) are also trailing the broader market, but have managed to notch double-digit gains in 2019.

Las Vegas Sands has been hurt by the trade war between the U.S. and China (and what it could mean for the latter’s economy) as well as the Hong Kong protests. While the Chinese gambling hub of Macau has somewhat recovered from last year’s doldrums, and analysts are split on whether or not there will be better days ahead, Las Vegas Sands has also struggled with uneven earnings this year.

What’s new. On Friday, Las Vegas Sands stock got a boost on news that the company will be added to the S&P 500 index on Oct. 3, replacing Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR). Las Vegas Sands stock is up 6% to $59.21 this morning.

Editor's Choice

Nektar, a biopharmaceutical firm, was once one of the index’s best performers. However that’s changed this year, as Nektar has been one of the worst-performing stocks through the end of last month, plunging most recently in August, when a poor earnings report and manufacturing issues caused the shares to fall 37%.

Nektar will be replacing Sotheby’s (BID) in the S&P 400, as the latter is being acquired, with the deal expected to close on Oct. 3.

Looking ahead. It’s not unusual for a company’s stock to get a boost when added to a major index. Inclusion in the S&P 500 can trigger purchases by passive index products as well as institutional investors, who may be benchmarked to specific indexes. Investors may also see inclusion as a bullish sign for a company’s future earnings potential.

However, gains aren’t always in the bag. Walgreens Boots Alliance stock (WBA) was added to the Dow Jones Industrial Average last summer. Shares are down 20% so far this year, and off 25% in the latest 12 months, another victim of the curse of the Dow (although Barron’s noted at the time that it was a bad move). Walgreens replaced General Electric (GE) after the embattled conglomerate was booted from that index (of which it was an original member). GE stock has lost 16% in the latest 12 months, but it’s up 25% year to date.
